results.title: Olympic Games, Melbourne, Australia, 1956
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympics warranted the Straford Brothers using their cherished stock of coloured film to capture this unique event. Original footage of the Athletics field (notably pole vaulting), swimming and diving events in the pool have been compiled by Frank years later with additional video content and a voiceover. Despite shooting some of this additional footage on his living room floor (inadvertantly including a glimpse of shagpile carpet) and such ‘special effects’ as a whiteboard marker illustrating points on a map, the documentary has a lot of interesting detail about the event; about their personal experience of it and the novelty of seeing OB Television crews in action.

results.title: Blue
results.creator_credit: Curtis Wehrfritz, Michael Pacek, Bruce McDonald and Don McKellar
results.brief_description: Canadian horror director David Cronenberg puts in an impressive performance as a bored carpert factory executive whose daily routine involves minor flirtations with his secretary and cronic masturbation in the privacy of his office. This explicit and ultimately melancholy tale of pornography and loneliness is intercut with a 1960s era stag loop called ‘The bellboy and the bored housewife’ and features the film’s star reminiscing about her experiences in the sex trade.

results.title: I Hung back, held fire, danced and lied
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: In I hung back, held fire, danced and lied, Kalin confronts loss, intimacy and estrangement. This visually arresting piece is constructed of Super-8 fragments that document familiar and foreign spaces, lovers and strangers. Rapidly intercut with these images are brief glimpses of names of individuals who have died from AIDS — some famous, others not so well known — that further notions of anonymity and immortality. Kalin’s imagery serves as an ‘imprint’ of the living world, preserving for an unknown viewer personal experiences that have already fled. Kalin concludes with a quote from The Black Boy Looks on the White Boy by James Baldwin: “I hung back, held fire, dance and lied. I was not going to come crawling out of my ruined house, all bloody, no, baby, sing no sad songs for me.

results.title: Blind grace
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: New York City — a huge, slow pulse of light steaming through daytime and night time. A study of the soul of the city, its radiance, its isolates and its irates — the special souls who are lost to the vision of the workaday world but scorched into the vision of Cohen’s video world. A world of blindness, grace and vision. A world made more sacred by noise — the special noise composed in response to the city’s scorching radiance, another kind of soul music.

results.title: Roland Robinson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
A poet with a strong attachment to the Australian landscape, Roland Robinson has a deep interest in Aboriginal lore, and performs his poetry with a memorable verve.

results.title: The Trout harvest
results.creator_credit: Ted Davis, Victoria. Dept. of Fisheries and Wildlife and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: The Snobs Creek fish hatchery was newly established at this time, and this film shows how the fish are bred from the egg stage to liberation into rivers and lakes. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1961.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ted Davis, Victoria. Dept. of Fisheries and Wildlife and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Life is More Pleasant with Wine
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation
results.brief_description: Presents the joys of drinking wine, a harmonious accompaniment to many activities. Suggests times, places and accompaniments for wine; discusses the qualities and features of each type of wine, the type of glass required; and how best to serve it.

results.title: Five short films by Akram Zaatari
results.brief_description: Filmmaker and video artist Akram Zaatari was born in Saida, Lebanon in 1966 and currently lives in Beirut. His art practice also includes photography, installation, critical writing and curating. “Teach me”: By constructing new meaning out of recycled TV news footage, the filmmaker creates a thought-provoking statement against violence. “Countdown” This personal reflection on film and TV mixes footage of real-life war and reel entertainment. Zaatari explores our sense of real-time transmission and movement through space as we experience them in televised images of breaking news. “Gift” looks at Lebanon’s summertime beach boys. One boy begs the filmmaker to let him join the soccer players on the beach so he can be on TV. “Reflections”: Memories and images of childhood are reflected both on the screen and in the small mirror that a young boy plays with. “A family portrait” is a profile of a young, modern Lebanese family who are having their family photos taken. This multi-layered work examines the differences and similarities between real life and the synthetic world of TV and film. In Arabic with English subtitles.
